text: evening, Acts chapter number 11, Acts chapter number 11, and I would say for our text this evening, if you're taking notes, that we'll be looking at verses 19 through 26 of Acts chapter number 11, but the truth be told, we're going to go forward through the next couple of chapters of the book of Acts and pick out a few things that take place. And really, as we look at this passage of Scripture this evening, and then look at a few additional portions of the book of Acts, I really want to spend a few moments tonight and consider the church in Antioch. And it's interesting, if we were to be asked, if someone were to ask you or ask me, what do you know about the church in Antioch? Certainly, if you've read the Bible, if you've been around church for any length of time, there are some things that you might be able to say about the church in Antioch, and one of the answers that might be given with regard to the church in Antioch is they were first called Christians in Antioch, and you would be correct, and maybe someone would say something to the effect of being the church that sent out the first missionaries, and you would be correct. And certainly, there's some information that we know about the church of Antioch, and as I was just kind of meditating upon this church and really thinking about the church in Antioch and beginning to allow myself to just think about and to see what the Lord says in His word about this church, I was encouraged, but I was also challenged. I believe that there is no perfect church. I do not believe that there's a perfect church. I believe that there are churches that seek to obey God and seek to follow God, churches that maybe we would say are model churches, are exemplary in their behavior and their conduct. And I would say this evening that the church at Antioch, the church in Antioch, would be such a church. I believe that as we study and look through the pages of Scripture that God gives us with regard to this church, we would say they were doing things well. They were serving the Lord, and that's commendable. That's exemplary. I find that as I would think about the church in Antioch, there really isn't a ton that we know about the church, biblically speaking. There's no letter written to the church in Antioch. There's no, you know, big dissortation that God gives us, but we are given some information that would help us to be encouraged and help us to be challenged. I think about this. If you notice in verse number 26, the last part of the verse, it says, and the disciples were called Christians first in Antioch. And honestly, it was that phrase of Scripture that really caught my attention and caused me to begin to meditate upon this thought that really was the start of this message for this evening. And that's this. What was it about these believers, these disciples, that made them be called Christians? What was it about this group of people? And as we begin to look at the Scriptures, and I begin to make note of some things about these believers, I hope this evening that you would be encouraged like I have been. I pray that we would be challenged corporately and individually as I have been challenged through considering these few things about this church in Antioch. If I were to give a title for the message this evening, it would simply be that statement, the disciples were called Christians. The disciples were called Christians. Now, the word disciple is simply, it refers to a pupil, a person, a learner. And we find that we would refer to the disciples, the twelve disciples, we would refer to Peter and John and those fellas as being the disciples of Christ, and rightly so. And Jesus would say, if any men are going to follow me, here's what he has to do to be a disciple of mine, and so on and so forth. We find that the word Christian means to be a follower of Christ. Jesus said, follow me, and I will make you fishers of men. We find that Peter would later say in the book of 1 Peter that Jesus left us an example that you should follow his steps. The reality is that as New Testament believers in 2021, we have the responsibility, shall I say we have the privilege, of being followers of Jesus Christ. I would say this, that we've been instructed to follow Jesus, and it is our right and our privilege to be able to serve him and to follow him, and what joy it is. But I would say this, Jesus never told us that it would be easy to follow Christ. He never said that it would be easy to follow him. In fact, if you were to read the record of what I mentioned a moment ago in Mark's gospel, we'll look at what he says with regard to this truth. Jesus never said that it would be easy to follow him. I think of Caleb and Joshua. I think of Caleb as it says often of him in the Old Testament, that he wholly followed the Lord his God, completely. He wholly followed the Lord his God. It wasn't easy for Joshua and Caleb to follow the Lord. It wasn't popular. Following Jesus, what a joy, what a blessing. But it's not always easy. And I want you to notice, the Bible says in verse number 4 of Acts chapter number 8, Therefore they that were scattered abroad went everywhere preaching the word. So the connection is given to us in Acts 11 and verse number 19, that these individuals that were scattered abroad because of the persecution, that they traveled as far as Phineas, Cyprus, and Antioch, they were preaching the word to none but unto the Jews only. Now I'm thankful for the preaching of the cross. I'm thankful for the preaching of the gospel of Jesus Christ. I want you to go back and read Acts 13 and 14 so that you can understand what was rehearsed by Paul and Barnabas when the church gathered together. I think it was a joyous time. I think it was a time in which individuals from this church had the privilege of hearing how their prayers were answered, how God was working. I believe that this reunion that had extensive rehearsing of all that God had done with them, I think it led to a high level of rejoicing. I think that they were rejoicing to hear of what God was doing and how God was working. It says in verse 28, and there they abode long time with the disciples. To me, when you read verse 28, I think it helps us to see the excitement that these believers had, and it helps us to understand that they weren't eager to get out. What do I mean by that? They were rejoicing in what God was doing and what God had done, and they were excited to be part of it. And they abode there a long time with the disciples. I'm not sure that anyone was, alright Paul, you've got to wrap it up, you've only got a couple of minutes left. I just don't picture that. In fact, in just a little while, Paul's going to be preaching through the night, and Eutychus is going to die because he was preaching so long. They were there for a long time. And I know that it says, and there they abode long time with the disciples. It wasn't just a long meeting that they had, there was time in which they stayed there. In fact, if you look at the end of chapter number 15, the Bible says in verse number 35, Paul also and Barnabas continued in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord with many others also. And so I understand that it was not just an initial meeting that was a lengthy time, but I believe that it was. They rehearsed everything that God was doing, but then they were there and they were rejoicing together and serving together and seeing God continue to use them. I ask this evening, how does a church get to a place where the church in Antioch is at the end of Acts 14? How do you get to the place where you're rejoicing with those that have been sent out from your ministry, rehearsing in all that God has done or rejoicing as you're hearing the rehearsing of all that God has done, or require some obedience to God? It requires some instruction, some growth, some living for Christ. And as we engage in those things, and as we say we want to be a church that is able to rejoice as we hear all that God has been doing, then we need to follow the pattern that we see here in these portions of Scripture about the church in Antioch. It is my desire that God would use us as Fellowship Baptist Church in a great and mighty way, that we would impact our community in our world with the Gospel of Jesus Christ. It is my prayer that souls would be saved through our ministry, that we would see the waters of baptism stirred, that we would see people added unto the church, that we would see people called from our midst to go into ministry, to serve in various capacities, because they've learned to obey God. They've learned to live for Christ. The disciples were called Christians. They were followers of Christ. If someone were to ask you, how do you identify yourself? I know I said this in a sermon not long ago, but I hope that we would say, I'm a follower of Jesus Christ. I'm a disciple of his, a follower of Christ, a Christian. This evening, I hope that you're encouraged by looking at these passages of Scripture about the church in Antioch. But more than being encouraged, I hope also that we would be challenged. Are these things said about me personally that are said about these believers personally? Are these things said about us corporately that are said about this church corporately? Oh, that God would use us for his honor and for his glory. The time is short. We don't know how long we have. But oh, that we would make every day count for Christ. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. We thank you for the privilege of serving you. God, as we look at this church in Antioch and seek to be encouraged and challenged, I pray that the Holy Spirit of God would work in each life as only He is able. Take the Word of God and minister effectively that decisions would be made that would please Thee. We pray that you'd have your will and way in our lives individually, in our church corporately. We pray that we'd obey you and we thank you for it. In Christ's name we pray, amen.

segments.text: evening, Acts chapter number 11, Acts chapter number 11, and I would say for our text this
evening, if you're taking notes, that we'll be looking at verses 19 through 26 of Acts
chapter number 11, but the truth be told, we're going to go forward through the next
couple of chapters of the book of Acts and pick out a few things that take place.
And really, as we look at this passage of Scripture this evening, and then look at a
few additional portions of the book of Acts, I really want to spend a few moments tonight
and consider the church in Antioch.
And it's interesting, if we were to be asked, if someone were to ask you or ask me, what
do you know about the church in Antioch?
Certainly, if you've read the Bible, if you've been around church for any length of time,
there are some things that you might be able to say about the church in Antioch, and one
of the answers that might be given with regard to the church in Antioch is they were first
called Christians in Antioch, and you would be correct, and maybe someone would say something
to the effect of being the church that sent out the first missionaries, and you would
be correct.
And certainly, there's some information that we know about the church of Antioch, and as
I was just kind of meditating upon this church and really thinking about the church in Antioch
and beginning to allow myself to just think about and to see what the Lord says in His
word about this church, I was encouraged, but I was also challenged.
I believe that there is no perfect church.
I do not believe that there's a perfect church.
I believe that there are churches that seek to obey God and seek to follow God, churches
that maybe we would say are model churches, are exemplary in their behavior and their
conduct.
And I would say this evening that the church at Antioch, the church in Antioch, would be
such a church.
I believe that as we study and look through the pages of Scripture that God gives us with
regard to this church, we would say they were doing things well.
They were serving the Lord, and that's commendable.
That's exemplary.
I find that as I would think about the church in Antioch, there really isn't a ton that
we know about the church, biblically speaking.
There's no letter written to the church in Antioch.
There's no, you know, big dissortation that God gives us, but we are given some information
that would help us to be encouraged and help us to be challenged.
I think about this.
If you notice in verse number 26, the last part of the verse, it says, and the disciples
were called Christians first in Antioch.
And honestly, it was that phrase of Scripture that really caught my attention and caused
me to begin to meditate upon this thought that really was the start of this message
for this evening.
And that's this.
What was it about these believers, these disciples, that made them be called Christians?
What was it about this group of people?
And as we begin to look at the Scriptures, and I begin to make note of some things about
these believers, I hope this evening that you would be encouraged like I have been.
I pray that we would be challenged corporately and individually as I have been challenged
through considering these few things about this church in Antioch.
If I were to give a title for the message this evening, it would simply be that statement,
the disciples were called Christians.
The disciples were called Christians.
Now, the word disciple is simply, it refers to a pupil, a person, a learner.
And we find that we would refer to the disciples, the twelve disciples, we would refer to Peter
and John and those fellas as being the disciples of Christ, and rightly so.
And Jesus would say, if any men are going to follow me, here's what he has to do to
be a disciple of mine, and so on and so forth.
We find that the word Christian means to be a follower of Christ.
Jesus said, follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.
We find that Peter would later say in the book of 1 Peter that Jesus left us an example
that you should follow his steps.
The reality is that as New Testament believers in 2021, we have the responsibility, shall
I say we have the privilege, of being followers of Jesus Christ.
And what a tremendous blessing it is to be a follower of Christ, and to determine that
we're going to follow him.
We sing songs about following Jesus, and we sing about I have decided to follow Jesus.
It's a song that we sing with children, and we encourage them in their Sunday school classes,
in their junior churches, in their Awana meetings, to learn about following Jesus.
I would say this, that we've been instructed to follow Jesus, and it is our right and our
privilege to be able to serve him and to follow him, and what joy it is.
But I would say this, Jesus never told us that it would be easy to follow Christ.
He never said that it would be easy to follow him.
In fact, if you were to read the record of what I mentioned a moment ago in Mark's gospel,
we'll look at what he says with regard to this truth.
In Mark chapter number 8, in verse number 34, the Bible says,
And when he had called the people unto him with his disciples also, he said unto them,

the Lord his God, completely.

It wasn't easy for Joshua and Caleb to follow the Lord.

It's not always popular.
